title: Joash's Reign and Temple Repair
shortSummary: This chapter recounts King Joash's reign, highlighting his initial faithfulness under the guidance of Jehoiada the priest, including the significant restoration of the temple. After Jehoiada's death, Joash turns away from God, leading to prophetic rebuke, judgment, and ultimately his violent death.
timeline: c. 835-796 BC - Reign of King Joash in Judah

keyCharacters.name: Joash
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who began to reign at seven years old; initially faithful and responsible for temple repairs but later turned away from God.

keyCharacters.name: Jehoiada
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who guided Joash faithfully, overseeing temple restoration and spiritual revival during his lifetime.

keyCharacters.name: Zechariah
keyCharacters.description: Son of Jehoiada and a prophet who boldly rebuked the people and king for their disobedience, ultimately martyred by stoning.

keyCharacters.name: Zabad and Jehozabad
keyCharacters.description: Servants of King Joash who conspired and killed him as judgment for his sins and the murder of Zechariah.

definitions.definition: Members of the tribe of Levi set apart for religious duties, including temple service and assisting the priests.

outline.heading: Joash’s Early Reign and Temple Restoration
outline.description: Joash begins his reign at age seven and, under Jehoiada’s guidance, leads a successful campaign to repair the temple, organizing the people to contribute funds and employing skilled workers to restore God’s house.

outline.heading: Death and Burial of Jehoiada
outline.description: Jehoiada dies at an advanced age and is honored with burial among the kings for his faithfulness and good works toward God and Israel.

outline.heading: Joash’s Apostasy and Prophetic Rebuke
outline.description: After Jehoiada’s death, Joash turns to idolatry, provoking God’s wrath. The prophet Zechariah confronts the people but is stoned to death by the king’s command.

outline.heading: Judgment on Joash and His Death
outline.description: Syria attacks Judah as divine judgment for Joash’s unfaithfulness. Later, Joash is assassinated by his own servants, and unlike his ancestors, he is not buried in the royal tombs.

application: Remain faithful to God’s guidance and spiritual leadership, as Joash did under Jehoiada, to experience blessing and restoration.
Recognize the danger of turning away from God after seasons of faithfulness, and repent promptly to avoid judgment.
Heed prophetic warnings and correction, understanding that God’s messengers call us back to obedience for our good.
Remember that leadership carries responsibility before God, and unfaithfulness can bring severe consequences.

keyVerses.text: And Joash did that which was right in the sight of the LORD all the days of Jehoiada the priest.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the positive impact of godly leadership and mentorship on a young king’s faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: And the Spirit of God came upon Zechariah the son of Jehoiada the priest, which stood above the people, and said unto them, Thus saith God, Why transgress ye the commandments of the LORD, that ye cannot prosper? because ye have forsaken the LORD, he hath also forsaken you.
keyVerses.significance: Zechariah’s prophetic message reveals the spiritual principle that forsaking God leads to failure and judgment.

keyVerses.text: Thus Joash the king remembered not the kindness which Jehoiada his father had done to him, but slew his son. And when he died, he said, The LORD look upon it, and require it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse exposes the tragic consequences of Joash’s ungratefulness and disobedience, underscoring the seriousness of rejecting God’s servants.

keyVerses.text: For the army of the Syrians came with a small company of men, and the LORD delivered a very great host into their hand, because they had forsaken the LORD God of their fathers. So they executed judgment against Joash.
keyVerses.significance: This verse demonstrates God’s sovereign judgment against unfaithfulness, showing that even a small enemy force can prevail when God withdraws His protection.
